repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Following up the discussion on the mailing list. I got to the point where I can use the new syntax:

- [X] Write a srctree test that creates various types of external ctypedef classes, add one that overrides a python-level @property with a cython one. This is a continuation of the test added in #2629 
- [X] Add `decorator` child and outer attributes to `CFuncDefNode`. ~I simply copied this from `DefNode`, is it required?~ - yes, seems to be required
- [X] ~Add a `DecoratorTransform.visit_CFuncDefNode` function based on `DecoratorTransform.visit_DefNode` and verify it is reached while parsing the `ctypedef class`.~
- [x] ~Found the point at which the attribute lookup should become a property function call (I think) is in `AttributeNode.analyse_attribute`. But it seems the entry is wrong, I need to either~ 

- ~fix the entry in `PropertyNode.analyse_declarations` and somehow make sure it is used instead of the old entry~
- ~change the code in `CFuncDefNode.analyse_declarations` and remove the `DecoratorTransform.visit_CFuncDefNode` function~

Any hints would be welcome.

Edit: added a new pass, ~still not working~

comment_data.body: This XXX is hit if I remove `DecoratorTransform.visit_CFuncDefNode`, and the entry is registered properly for attribute lookup for `Foo.field0`, `Foo.field1`, `Foo.field2`, but then of course fails since the entry is a function `int (Foo)` not the function call.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2339,6 +2340,16 @@ def code_object(self):
         return self.py_func.code_object if self.py_func else None
 
     def analyse_declarations(self, env):
+        if self.decorators:
+            for decorator in self.decorators:
+                func = decorator.decorator
+                if func.is_name:
+                    if func.name == 'classmethod' or func.name == 'staticmethod':
+                        error(self.pos, "Cannot handle these decorators yet")
+                    if func.name == 'property':
+                        # XXX DO SOMETHING HERE???
+                        pass
+

comment_data.body: The entry from `env.declare_property` is not being overridden by the later entry from the body.stats[0].entry, even if I enable the code here
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5023,6 +5034,13 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         self.entry = env.declare_property(self.name, self.doc, self.pos)
         self.entry.scope.directives = env.directives
         self.body.analyse_declarations(self.entry.scope)
+        # XXX DO SOMETHING HERE???
+        if 0 and self.is_wrapper:
+            entry = self.body.stats[0].entry
+            entry.is_property = 1
+            entry.doc = self.doc
+            env.property_entries[-1] = entry
+            env.entries[self.name] = entry

comment_data.body: It is not clear to me how these are used, and if I need to add `'decorators'` to these.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2319,7 +2319,8 @@ class CFuncDefNode(FuncDefNode):
     #  is_static_method whether this is a static method
     #  is_c_class_method whether this is a cclass method
 
-    child_attrs = ["base_type", "declarator", "body", "py_func_stat"]
+    child_attrs = ["base_type", "declarator", "body", "py_func_stat", "decorators"]
+    outer_attrs = ["decorators"]

comment_data.body: We should probably error on everything but this for now.

comment_data.body: We'd need a pass, likely somewhere before AnalyzeTypes, that rewrites all Foo.field0 into Foo.field0().
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2339,6 +2340,16 @@ def code_object(self):

comment_data.body: What is AnalyzeTypes? I turned on DebugFlags.debug_verbose_pipeline (since I am running a srctree test which runs cythonize in a subprocess, I needed to actually edit the file) and see a AnalyseDeclarationsTransform which is calling PropertyNode.analyse_declarations which is calling this function (CFuncDefNode.analyse_declarations) via line 5036 since it is part of the PropertyNode.body. But I couldn't figure out how to override the results of env.declare_property on line 5034 to make the CFuncDefNode's entry into the one called for `field0`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2339,6 +2340,16 @@ def code_object(self):
         return self.py_func.code_object if self.py_func else None

+        if self.decorators:
+            for decorator in self.decorators:
+                func = decorator.decorator
+                if func.is_name:
+                    if func.name == 'classmethod' or func.name == 'staticmethod':
+                        error(self.pos, "Cannot handle these decorators yet")
+                    if func.name == 'property':

+                        pass
+

comment_data.body:
`child_attrs` is used for the tree traversal during transformations. Nodes (and lists of nodes) in these attributes will be visited, in the given order. Attributes that are not in this list will not be traversed.

`outer_attrs` is a subset that semantically belongs to the outer scope (or namespace). Functions have their own internal scope, but decorators are not evaluated in that scope but the outer one. I think the additions above are correct.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2319,7 +2319,8 @@ class CFuncDefNode(FuncDefNode):
     #  is_static_method whether this is a static method
     #  is_c_class_method whether this is a cclass method
 
-    child_attrs = ["base_type", "declarator", "body", "py_func_stat"]
+    child_attrs = ["base_type", "declarator", "body", "py_func_stat", "decorators"]
+    outer_attrs = ["decorators"]

comment_data.body: +1, also everything that is not a simple name or `property.setter` etc.

comment_data.body: The `AnalyseDeclarationsTransform` cannot currently replace tree nodes (at least not the one it currently handles). Robert meant the `AnalyseExpressionsTransform`, which can do that but might run too late. I'd say, somewhere between the `AnalyseDeclarationsTransform` and the `ControlFlowAnalysis` steps would be the right place for a new transform that replaces these property usages.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body: I think it would be nice to reduce the code duplication here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

         node.decorators = None
         return self.chain_decorators(node, decs, node.name)
 
+    def visit_CFuncDefNode(self, node):

comment_data.body: We can use this option now.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -78,32 +111,94 @@ cdef extern from "foo_nominal.h":
             int field2 "f2"
 
 def sum(Foo f):
-    # the f.__getattr__('field0') is replaced in c by f->f0
+    # Note - not a cdef function but compiling the f.__getattr__('field0')
+    # notices the alias and replaces the __getattr__ in c by f->f0 anyway
     return f.field0 + f.field1 + f.field2
 
+######## getter1.pyx ########
+
+# Access base Foo fields from C via getter functions
+
+
+cdef extern from "foo.h":
+    ctypedef class foo_extension.Foo [object FooStructOpaque]:
+    # Importing will warn until we can use this syntax
+    # ctypedef class foo_extension.Foo [object FooStructOpaque, check_size]:

commit.message: WIP ENH: allow @property decorator on external ctypedef classes
ENH: handle c-level property decorator to produce a cfunc call
BUG: fix test to use correct macros, functions for c-level getters
whoops, staticmethod is a valid cdef decorator

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: ENH: allow @property decorator on external ctypedef classes
